subj-group.subject: Special Section: Beyond English: Translators Talk about Murakami Haruki

title-group.article-title: Murakami Haruki's Sound of Music: Personal Impressions of a Translator

In Japanese:つまりね、こういう音楽を聴いていると自分が何もない広々とし た空間にいるような気がするの。そこはほとんど広々としていて、仕切りとい うものがない。壁もなく、天井もない。そしてそこで私は何も考えなくていい、 何も言わなくていい、何もしなくていい。ただそこにいればいいの。 Murakami Haruki, “Onna no inai otokotachi," in Onna no inai otokotachi (Tokyo: Bungei Shunju, 2014)，268.
Murakami Haruki, "As Translator, As Novelist: The Translator's Afterword," trans. Ted Goossen, in Allen and Bernofsky, In Translation, 174-175.
Murakami, Tony Takitani, trans. Ursula Grafe.
レコードの山がすっかり消えてしまうと，トニ一滝谷は今度こそ本当にひとり ぼっちになった。Murakami, "Tonii Takitani," 159; the English translation is from Murakami, “Tony Takitani," trans. Jay Rubin, 81.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MGCTG 1 inPdE. Accessed June 30，2014.
"Murakami, Japan, and America" see Rebecca Suter, The Japanization of Modernity: Murakami Haruki between Japan and the United States (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Asia Center, 2008), 35-59.

Lawrence Venuti, "The Difference That Translation Makes: The Translator's Unconscious." In Translation Studies: Perspectives on an Emerging Discipline, ed. Alessandra Riccardi (Cambridge, U.K.: Cambridge University Press 2002), 237.
